Features in Soils

Redoximorphic Features in Soils
Redoximorphic Features in Soils

• Extended periods of saturation can cause anaerobic conditions to develop leading to the formation of redoximorphic features in the soil profile.
• Extended periods of saturation
can cause anaerobic conditions
to develop leading to the
formation of redoximorphic
features in the soil profile.

• Features occurring in the upper part of the soil profile may be indicative of hydric soil conditions.
• Features occurring in the upper
part of the soil profile may be
indicative of hydric soil
conditions.

• Major criteria for developing field indicators for identifying and delineating hydric soils • Morphological evidence
• Major criteria for developing field
indicators for identifying and
delineating hydric soils
• Morphological evidence

documenting wetland function
documenting wetland function

Newly-Formed Redoximorphic Features in Soils • Quantity and nature of redoximorphic features can be affected by soil texture, mineralogy, temperature, organic carbon content, and vegetation
Newly-Formed Redoximorphic
Features in Soils
• Quantity and nature of redoximorphic features
can be affected by soil texture, mineralogy,
temperature, organic carbon content, and
vegetation

• Limited knowledge exists regarding the rate of
• Limited knowledge exists regarding the rate of

redoximorphic feature development
redoximorphic feature development

• Problem settings:
• Problem settings:

– recently deposited, exposed, or saturated soil
– recently deposited, exposed, or saturated soil

materials such as in floodplains
materials such as in floodplains

– disturbed areas where hydrology has been altered or
– disturbed areas where hydrology has been altered or

where fill materials have been added
where fill materials have been added

– wetland restoration or wetland construction projects
– wetland restoration or wetland construction projects

Experimental Approach
Experimental Approach

• Collect undisturbed soil cores from soils lacking redoximorphic features in the upper part and establish as experimental mesocosms
• Collect undisturbed soil cores from soils lacking
redoximorphic features in the upper part and
establish as experimental mesocosms

• Expose soil mesocosms to saturated conditions for varying lengths of time in both greenhouse and field settings
• Expose soil mesocosms to saturated conditions
for varying lengths of time in both greenhouse
and field settings

• Utilize three soil series and two wetland plant species to evaluate effects of differing soil properties and vegetation on redoximorphic feature development
• Utilize three soil series and two wetland plant
species to evaluate effects of differing soil
properties and vegetation on redoximorphic
feature development

• In set time cycles, dissect cores and described
• In set time cycles, dissect cores and described

all newly-formed redoximorphic features
all newly-formed redoximorphic features

Vegetation Treatments
Vegetation Treatments

• Three vegetation treatments: • 1) control, non-vegetated • 2) Echnichloa crusgalli
• Three vegetation treatments:
• 1) control, non-vegetated
• 2) Echnichloa crusgalli

(barnyard grass)
(barnyard grass)

• 3) Juncus Effusus (soft rush)
• 3) Juncus Effusus (soft rush)

- oxidized rhyzospheres
- oxidized rhyzospheres

Soft Rush (Juncus effusus L.)
Soft Rush (Juncus effusus L.)

Barnyard Grass (Echnichloa crusgalli L.)
Barnyard Grass (Echnichloa crusgalli L.)

Greenhouse Experimental Design
Greenhouse Experimental Design

• Randomized Block Design
• Randomized Block Design

– Three soil series – Three vegetation treatments (including control) – Each treatment combination replicated – Total of 108 mesocosms
– Three soil series
– Three vegetation treatments (including control)
– Each treatment combination replicated
– Total of 108 mesocosms

• Time Series
• Time Series

– 6 16 week hydrologic cycles in the greenhouse (8
– 6 16 week hydrologic cycles in the greenhouse (8

weeks of saturation, 8 weeks of oxidation)
weeks of saturation, 8 weeks of oxidation)

– At the end of each cycle, a sampling set of 18 cores
– At the end of each cycle, a sampling set of 18 cores

was removed, dissected, and all newly-formed redoximorphic features were documented
was removed, dissected, and all newly-formed
redoximorphic features were documented

DEPLETED ZONE ALONG ROOT CHANNEL

Iron oxide coating along macropore

Feature Formation Trends
Feature Formation Trends

• Majority of features are iron concentrations, fine to very fine, mostly faint to distinct along root channels, pores, and ped faces
• Majority of features are iron concentrations, fine
to very fine, mostly faint to distinct along root
channels, pores, and ped faces

• Percentage of feature expression has increased
• Percentage of feature expression has increased

in later sampling cycles
in later sampling cycles

• Mesos from the codorus series have the
• Mesos from the codorus series have the

greatest feature expression (mostly likely due to higher carbon content (1.5-2.0%) and better structure
greatest feature expression (mostly likely due to
higher carbon content (1.5-2.0%) and better
structure

• Vegetation treatment can influence the type of
• Vegetation treatment can influence the type of

concentration
concentration

Field Study: North Branch Rock Creek
Field Study: North Branch Rock Creek

• Two randomized plots of nine mesocosms each, three soil types in triplicate (18 cores)
• Two randomized plots
of nine mesocosms
each, three soil types
in triplicate (18 cores)

• Implanted into a

area. Plot 1 extracted

Conclusions
Conclusions

• Length of time soils are exposed to
• Length of time soils are exposed to

saturation conditions has greatest effect on feature expression
saturation conditions has greatest effect
on feature expression

• Soil properties and vegetation both affect
• Soil properties and vegetation both affect

redoximorphic feature development • Amount of carbon in soils is a limiting
redoximorphic feature development
• Amount of carbon in soils is a limiting

factor
factor

• Rate of feature formation faster in one
• Rate of feature formation faster in one

year in field as opposed to one year in the greenhouse
year in field as opposed to one year in the
greenhouse

Anticipated Benefits
Anticipated Benefits

• Expand the knowledge regarding the rate of newly-formed redoximorphic features in soils
• Expand the knowledge regarding the rate
of newly-formed redoximorphic features in
soils

• Provide insight interpreting
• Provide insight interpreting

hydromorphology and hydric status in In areas of recent deposition, exposure, landscape alteration or disturbance, and wetland restoration/ construction
hydromorphology and hydric status in In
areas of recent deposition, exposure,
landscape alteration or disturbance, and
wetland restoration/ construction
